sentences.text: On 1 January 2024, at 16:10 Japan Standard Time|JST (07:10 Coordinated Universal Time|UTC), a {{M|j|link=y}}7.6 ({{M|w|link=y}}7.5) earthquake struck {{Cvt|6|km|mi}} north-northeast of Suzu, Ishikawa|Suzu, located on the Noto Peninsula of Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. The Fault (geology)#Dip-slip faults|reverse-faulting shock achieved a maximum Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|JMA seismic intensity of ''Shindo 7'' and Modified Mercalli intensity scale|Modified Mercalli intensity of X–XI (''Extreme''). The shaking and accompanying tsunami caused widespread destruction on the Noto Peninsula, particularly in the towns of Suzu, Ishikawa|Suzu, Wajima, Ishikawa|Wajima, Noto, Ishikawa|Noto and Anamizu. Damage was also recorded in Toyama Prefecture|Toyama and Niigata Prefecture|Niigata prefectures.

sentences.text: The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) officially named this earthquake the {{Nihongo|'''2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake'''|令和6年能登半島地震|Reiwa 6-nen Noto-hantō Jishin|lead=yes}}. It led to Japan's first major Tsunami Warning (Japan)|tsunami warning since the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tōhoku earthquake, and a tsunami of {{cvt|7.45|m|ft|0}} was measured along the Sea of Japan coast.

sentences.text: The Noto Peninsula lies on the southeastern margin of the Sea of Japan, which was formed by back-arc basin|back-arc rifting related to subduction of the Pacific plate beneath the Eurasian plate along the Japan Trench. This process began during the Early Miocene, ending in the Middle Miocene. By the late Pliocene the tectonic regime changed to compression, probably associated with collision between the Izu–Bonin–Mariana Arc|Izu–Bonin Arc and Honshu. This led to reactivation of the rift faults in reverse sense, combined with inversion (geology)|inversion of the basins formed by these faults. Currently Japan is situated on the convergent boundary|convergent boundaries between the Pacific, Philippine Sea plate|Philippine Sea, Okhotsk Plate|Okhotsk and Amurian Plates. Along the island arc's east and southeast coasts, subduction of the Pacific and Philippine Sea plates occurs at the Japan Trench and Nankai Trough, respectively. The west coast of Honshu, bordering the Sea of Japan, is a north–south trending convergent boundary between the Amurian and Okhotsk Plates. It has been proposed that it is an incipient subduction zone, consisting of eastward-dipping thrust faults.

sentences.text: The rifting and subsequent inversion has created a series of faults along the coast that have the potential to move and cause earthquakes, in the range of {{M|w}}6.8–7.9, in many cases with tsunamis. Major earthquakes and tsunamis along this boundary occurred in 1833 Shōnai earthquake|1833, 1940 Shakotan earthquake|1940, 1964 Niigata earthquake|1964, 1983 Sea of Japan earthquake|1983 and 1993 Okushiri earthquake|1993. The largest and most destructive tsunami in the Sea of Japan occurred in 1741 eruption of Oshima–Ōshima and the Kampo tsunami|1741 and was attributed to the eruption of Oshima (Hokkaido)|Oshima. A fault known as the F43 (in the list of 60 faults evaluated) reaches the seabed just north of the Noto peninsula trending WSW–ENE. This southeast-dipping fault, which consists of two segments with a combined length of {{cvt|94.2|km}}, has been judged to be capable of producing an earthquake of {{M|w}}7.6.<ref name="Mulia20"/>

sentences.text: The northeastern tip of the Noto Peninsula has been subject to an earthquake swarm for the last three years, with the largest earthquake being 2023 Noto earthquake|a M<sub>JMA</sub> 6.5 event that took place in May 2023. The 1 January 2024 mainshock was the strongest to hit the peninsula since records began in 1885.

sentences.text: Fluid upwelling may be occurring beneath the peninsula as evidenced by a {{cvt|70|mm}} uplift of the surface above the swarm. Seismologists considered the swarm unexpected as the peninsula lacked active volcanic or geothermal features to produce high-pressure fluids that would promote such seismic activity. These fluids may have originated from the upper mantle and migrated upwards into the crust through faults. Lubricated by fluids, these faults began producing earthquakes. No direct connection between the swarm and mainshock has been established, however, the swarm may have Coulomb stress transfer|induced stress on these faults as they moved.

The Japan Meteorological Agency recorded a magnitude of {{M|j|lnk=y}} 7.6. It was the largest earthquake to strike Ishikawa Prefecture|Ishikawa since at least 1885, and the largest to strike Mainland Japan since the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tōhoku earthquake.

sentences.text: According to a finite fault model released by the {{abbr|USGS|United States Geological Survey}}, the earthquake rupture extended over {{cvt|160|km}} by {{cvt|20|km}} from the southwestern Noto Peninsula to Sado Island along a southeast-dipping fault. Slip was mostly concentrated entirely beneath the peninsula. The zones of the largest slip occurred southwest of the hypocenter while little to no slip occurred on the segment offshore between the peninsula and island. The patch immediately southwest of the epicenter produced a displacement of {{cvt|5.992|m|ft|0}} beneath the peninsula's coast. Another zone of slip occurred further southwest beneath the same stretch of coastline, producing up to {{cvt|6.030|m|ft|0}} of slip beneath Motoichi. The fault likely ruptured towards the seafloor at the peninsula while little to no slip was observed on the seafloor between the peninsula and Sado Island. The entire rupture process took about 50 seconds with the greatest phase of seismic moment release occurring some 25 seconds after initiation.

sentences.text: Due to the lack of significant slip on the segment offshore between the peninsula and Sado Island, seismologist Kenji Satake said there is still potential for another magnitude 7.0 or larger earthquake and tsunami. Research led by Kimiyuki Asano at the Disaster Prevention Research Institute at Kyoto University analysed waveforms recorded by seismometers and determined the earthquake consisted of two subevents. The first subevent, measuring {{M|j}} 7.3, ruptured a fault beneath the peninsula, causing coastal uplift. A second subevent identical in magnitude ruptured the offshore segment 13 seconds after the completion of the first subevent.

Wajima's Minazuki Bay was uplifted {{cvt|4|m}} while at Nagahashimachi's fishing port, a tide gauge was rendered unusable because the seafloor was exposed.

sentences.text: The Geospatial Information Authority of Japan (GSI) said parts of the country moved up to {{cvt|1.3|m}} westwards with the maximum displacement observed at Wajima, Ishikawa|Wajima due to crustal deformation. At Anamizu, land shifted {{cvt|1|m}} westwards. However, the agency said these movements could be slope or local ground movement instead. The agency also added that crustal uplift of {{cvt|4|m}} occurred in western Wajima and {{cvt|1.1|m}} in northern Suzu, Ishikawa|Suzu. Near Wajima's port, the shoreline of a sandy beach was moved {{cvt|250|m}} seawards due to the coastal uplift. Uplift at Kaiso Fishing Port in Wajima by {{cvt|4|m}} exposed parts of the seafloor.

sentences.text: The coastline in the Kawaura district of Suzu moved {{cvt|175|m}} seawards due to the coastal uplift, while the land area expanded by a total of {{cvt|2.4|km2}}. A port in the Ozawa district of Wajima was entirely drained. A seaward movement of {{cvt|240|m}} was detected in the coasts of Monzenmachi and Kuroshimamachi districts in Wajima, as well as an expansion of {{cvt|4.4|km2}} in the Noto Peninsula. Areas in the northern part of the peninsula were also found to have risen while the southern sections, particularly in Anamizu, had subsided.

sentences.text: The {{abbr|GSI|Geospatial Information Authority of Japan}} said due to the land expansion by {{cvt|4.4|km2}}, Ishikawa Prefecture may have become larger than Fukui Prefecture in land area. The latter, having an area of {{cvt|4,190.54|km2}}, is {{cvt|4.34|km2}} larger than Ishikawa Prefecture, according to a survey in October 2023. However, this difference was expected to be temporary due to the effects of coastal erosion. It has been theorized that the coastal uplift may have fortuitously lessened the effects of the tsunami which followed the earthquake.

<ref>{{cite news|date=2 January 2024|title=How Japan's powerful earthquakes have shifted the land|last=Amos|first=Jonathan|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-67862306|access-date=14 May 2024|publisher=BBC News|language=en-GB}}</ref>

sentences.text: Across the mountainous region of the peninsula, landslides were widespread. particularly in the northeastern part of the peninsula. The number of landslides was estimated at 1,000. At least nine landslide dams were discovered in the Wajima area on 9 January, which had the potential to cause debris avalanches. In Wajima, a landslide dam caused water to overflow downstream into fields, potentially causing a collapse. In Jōetsu, Niigata, a landslide measuring {{cvt|16,000|m3}} buried a section of Japan National Route 8|National Route 8.

sentences.text: A Fault scarp|scarp trending east–west across a zone {{cvt|4|km}} long and {{cvt|0.1–0.4|km}} wide occurred along the Wakayama River in Suzu. The maximum vertical offset was {{cvt|2.2|m}} in Naka district, Wakayama town. These scarps did not display any observable horizontal displacement. It propagated through and displaced rice fields, roads and rivers among other features. The {{abbr|GSI|Geospatial Information Authority of Japan}} said these scarps may represent a fold in response to compressive forces due to the geology of the area. However, they did not rule out the scarp being the toe of a landslide, though this is a less probable explanation.

sentences.text: Surveys by the Japan Coast Guard revealed a section of uplifted seafloor south of the active fault trace. The seabed north of the Noto Peninsula lies {{cvt|40–90|m}} beneath the sea. The recent survey and survey results from the previous year suggested a {{cvt|3|m|adj=on}} uplift of the seafloor.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|title=Notohantō oki no kaitei de yaku 3 mētoru no ryūki o kakunin|script-title=ja:能登半島沖の海底で約 3 メートルの隆起を確認|language=ja|trans-title=Approximately 3-metre upheaval confirmed on the ocean floor off the coast of the Noto Peninsula|url=https://www.kaiho.mlit.go.jp/info/kouhou/r6/k240208/k240208.pdf|publisher=Japan Coast Guard|access-date=9 February 2024|date=8 February 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Japan Meteorological Agency said it recorded a maximum seismic intensity of 7 (''Shindo 7''), the highest level on its Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|seismic intensity scale, the first time that an earthquake of that intensity had been observed in the country since 2018 Hokkaido Eastern Iburi earthquake|2018. It corresponded to a maximum Modified Mercalli intensity of X–XI (''Extreme''). The USGS assigned a maximum intensity of IX (''Violent''). Intensity 6+ was recorded in Nanao, Ishikawa|Nanao, Suzu, Noto, Ishikawa|Noto and Anamizu. Intensity 6– was recorded in Nagaoka, Niigata|Nagaoka in Niigata Prefecture and in Ishikawa's Nakanoto. Due to the ground beneath Wajima and Anamizu comprising soft sediments, ground motions were amplified.

sentences.text: The earthquake generated aftershocks that extended {{cvt|160|km}} along a northeast–southwest trend. The largest aftershocks were recorded beneath the peninsula. About 15 minutes after the mainshock, a {{M|w}} 6.1 event was recorded. Two {{M|w}} 6.2 and 6.0 aftershocks were recorded on 9 January and 1 June, respectively.

sentences.text: Large parts of Japan's western coast, from Hokkaido to Nagasaki Prefectures were immediately placed under a Tsunami Warning (Japan)|tsunami warning after the earthquake struck, with evacuation orders issued in Ishikawa, Niigata, Toyama Prefecture|Toyama, and Yamagata prefectures. The earthquake triggered a major tsunami warning, the first one since the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake. Public broadcaster NHK said tsunami waves of {{cvt|5|m}} could be expected. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center said dangerous tsunami waves were possible within {{cvt|300|km}} of the epicenter.

sentences.text: The evacuation orders covered 62,000 people, with 1,000 evacuees finding shelter at the Japan Air Self-Defense Force base in Wajima in Ishikawa Prefecture. The major tsunami warning was later downgraded to a tsunami warning at 20:30, about four hours after the earthquake. These tsunami warnings were later downgraded to advisories, which were eventually lifted at 10:00 on 2 January, about 18 hours after the earthquake.

sentences.text: On the peninsula's northern coast, about 370 hectares of land was inundated. The first waves were reported to have arrived at around 16:21, The quicker-than-anticipated tsunami arrival meant people did not evacuate in time. Fumihiko Imamura, a member of the research team, said it may have been due to the close proximity of the fault to the coast or a possible submarine landslide in Toyama Bay. Tsunamis in the Sea of Japan have been observed to arrive faster than those along Japan's Pacific coast. Tsunami modelling executed by the University of Tokyo and Building Research Institute of Japan computed the tsunami to be {{cvt|3.6|m}} in Suzu; {{cvt|3|m}} in Noto; {{cvt|2.5|m}} in Shika and {{cvt|2|m}} in Jōetsu, Niigata.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|title=Notohantō jishin no tsunami shinsui, tōsho shirabe kara baizō 370 hekutāru ka… Wajima-shi hokugan nado de kōhan'i ni konseki|trans-title=Tsunami inundation caused by the Noto Peninsula earthquake may have doubled to 370 hectares from initial estimates... Traces can be seen over a wide area, including on the north coast of Wajima City|script-title=ja:能登半島地震の津波浸水、当初調べから倍増３７０ヘクタールか…輪島市北岸などで広範囲に痕跡|url=https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20240527-OYT1T50142/|access-date=30 May 2024|work=Yomiuri Shimbun|language=ja|date=27 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240527095930/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20240527-OYT1T50142/|archive-date=27 May 2024|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="jt"/> although a team of researchers from Tohoku University's International Research Institute of Disaster Science said the first waves reached the Noto Peninsula within a minute of the earthquake. Along the Noto Peninsula, the second wave was the largest and most destructive. In Suzu, the first waves were estimated to arrive one minute after the shock and two minutes later at Nanao. They also estimated Toyama was struck by the waves in about five minutes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tsunami reached Japan coast within roughly 1 minute of quake: study|url=https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240103_29/|access-date=4 January 2024|publisher=NHK World-Japan|date=3 January 2024|archive-date=3 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240103203517/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240103_29/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Tohoku University analyzes 'Tendency to be faster along the Sea of Japan'|language=ja|url=https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/20240104-OYT1T50149/|work=Yomiuri Shimbun|access-date=5 January 2024|archive-date=5 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240105095807/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/20240104-OYT1T50149/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Flooding by the tsunami exceeded {{cvt|4|m}} along the east and western part of the peninsula. In Suzu, the highest waves exceeded {{cvt|4.7|m}} at Misaki Town, destroying homes and damaging the seawall. At Shika's Kagami area, the tsunami was recorded at {{cvt|5.1|m}}. A run-up of about {{cvt|4.2|m}} was estimated at Shika based on the survey of warehouses and port facilities. Aerial photographs of Suzu suggested a wave height of {{cvt|3|m}} above sea level; subsequent analysis indicated a wave of {{cvt|4.5|m}} at Nanba, Misakimachi. Tsunami waves exceeding {{cvt|1.2|m|ft|0}} struck Wajima, A tide gauge at the Shika Nuclear Power Plant recorded a rise of {{cvt|3|m}} in tide level at between 17:45 and 18:00. The plant's operator later said that a {{cvt|4|m|adj=on}} wave reached the facility, which was built at an elevation of {{cvt|11|m}} above sea level and had a seawall measuring {{cvt|4|m}} high, at 17:45, without causing damage.

sentences.text: A tsunami measuring {{cvt|90|cm}} struck Kanazawa, while a tsunami of {{cvt|80|cm}} struck Toyama Prefecture and Sakata, Yamagata|Sakata, Yamagata Prefecture. Waves measuring {{cvt|50|cm}} were recorded in Nanao and Tsuruga Tobishima, Yamagata|Tobishima, and Sado Island. The tsunami was recorded in Tottori Prefecture with heights of {{cvt|0.6|m}} in Sakaiminato and {{cvt|0.2|m}} in Iwami, Tottori|Iwami; in Toyooka, Hyōgo Prefecture, it reached {{cvt|0.4|m}}. A {{cvt|0.4|m|adj=on}} tsunami was recorded at the port area of Maizuru, Kyoto Prefecture. In Hokkaido, waves of up to {{cvt|60|cm}} were reported in Setana, while {{cvt|50|cm}} waves struck Okushiri Island.<ref name="nhktsunami2"/>

sentences.text: At Funami Park, a public park {{cvt|600|m}} from the Seki River mouth in Jōetsu, the tsunami had a maximum height of {{cvt|7.45|m}}, the highest recorded in the disaster. The tsunami swept people away at the entrance of a building and in the park. The locally high waves may be attributed to the seafloor bathymetry concentrating the tsunami at a specific location. Video footage in Jōetsu, Niigata showed the tsunami approaching the rivermouth at 16:35, crashing into embankments and causing seawater to overflow. Evidence of tsunami sediments and marine flora suggested the tsunami reached at least {{cvt|5.5|km}} upstream from the river mouth. It also flowed along the Hokura River for {{cvt|1.6|km}} starting from its confluence at the Seki River. Wave heights along the coast southwest of the rivermouth were between {{cvt|1.5|m}} and {{cvt|5.0|m}}. Northeast of the rivermouth, they ranged from {{cvt|1.8|m}} to {{cvt|4.0|m}}. At Naoetsu beach, tsunami debris indicated {{cvt|2|m}} waves struck while {{cvt|3|km}} to the west in Tanhama beach, waves were estimated at {{cvt|4|m}}.

sentences.text: In northeastern Suzu, the tsunami was said to have arrived a minute following the earthquake. Homes were washed off their foundations and some were driven further inland. At least two people were killed by the tsunami in Ukai Horyumachi District, however the total tsunami death toll may have been at least 26 including 24 in Ukai Horyumachi. The tsunami in Ukai Horyumachi reached up to {{cvt|5.45|m}} and almost every building in the town within a block of the coast was swept away or damaged beyond repair. In Suzu City, many fishing vessels capsized or were carried onto land. Building collapses and overturned cars were observed from a news helicopter flyover of the city. A resident recalled tsunami waves washing over a road, picking up cars and debris. Ishikawa Prefecture's governor, Hiroshi Hase, said the tsunami flooded the Iida Port area by up to {{cvt|100|m}} inland. A study conducted by professor Shunichi Koshimura of Tohoku University found that the damage in Suzu was exacerbated by the seabed terrain of Toyama Bay.<ref name="rupture2"/>

<ref name="shikaTS"/> Tsunami observations in the peninsula were made difficult by the coastal uplift raising parts of the coast by up to {{cvt|4.1|m}} and extending the coastline further seawards.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ja:地盤隆起で津波観測不能に＝気象庁、震度７地震の震源近く―能登地震|title=Jiban ryūki de tsunami kansoku funō ni = Kishōchō, shindo 7 jishin no shingen chikaku ― Noto jishin|trans-title=Tsunami observation impossible due to ground upheaval = Japan Meteorological Agency, near epicenter of seismic intensity 7 earthquake – Noto Earthquake|language=ja|access-date=7 January 2024|publisher=Jiji Press|date=5 January 2024|url=https://sp.m.jiji.com/article/show/3135656|archive-date=6 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240106235209/https://sp.m.jiji.com/article/show/3135656|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the Shiromaru area of Noto, Ishikawa|Noto, homes were destroyed and a fire was started. About {{cvt|4.6|ha}} of coastline was damaged. The tsunami in Shiromaru reached {{cvt|5.58|m}}, one of the highest run ups recorded in the peninsula.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|date=3 January 2024|script-title=ja:【能登半島地震】背丈ほどの津波、住宅流され火災も 能登町・白丸 本紙記者ルポ|title=[Notohantō jishin] setake hodo no tsunami, jūtaku nagasa re kasai mo notochō Shiromaru honshi kisha rupo|trans-title=[Noto Peninsula Earthquake] Tsunami as tall as someone's height, houses washed away and fires, Shiromaru, Noto Town, Report by this newspaper reporter|language=ja|work=The Hokkoku Shimbun|url=https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/ea756623deebcc0eda346ff9a8f4fff0963fba1d|access-date=29 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240103043437/https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/ea756623deebcc0eda346ff9a8f4fff0963fba1d|archive-date=3 January 2024|url-status=live|publisher=Yahoo Japan}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|last=Toda|first=Sayuri|title=Surging tsunami captured by dash cam during narrow escape after Jan. 1 Japan quake|url=https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20240109/p2a/00m/0na/002000c|access-date=16 January 2024|work=Mainichi Shimbun|date=9 January 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="nototsunamifieldsvy"/> Heavy damage was recorded in the district with many houses swept away or destroyed. Most coastal homes that weren't destroyed were damaged beyond repair and later demolished. Out of 80 occupied households in Shiromaru, 60 were severely damaged by the tsunami and fires.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=ja: 津波被害の能登町白丸、住民が高台への住宅移転検討組織を立ち上げ|trans-title= Residents of tsunami-hit Noto town's Shiromaru set up group to consider relocating homes to higher ground|url=https://www.asahi.com/articles/ASS7C5DH0S7CPJLB00SM.html|website = asahi.com|date = July 12, 2024|access-date=January 11, 2025}}</ref>

<ref name="4threportTS">{{cite web|title=Reiwa 6-nen Notohantō jishin ni yoru tsunami shinsui han'i no kentō kekka (dai shi-pō)|script-title=ja:令和 6 年能登半島地震による津波浸水範囲の検討結果（第四報）|trans-title=Study results of tsunami inundation area due to the 2024 Noto Peninsula Earthquake (4th report)|url=http://disaster.ajg.or.jp/files/202401_Noto009.pdf|publisher=The Association of Japanese Geographers|access-date=16 January 2024|language=ja|date=14 January 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: On Hegurajima, the tsunami flooded homes and disabled basic services. Three people were stranded on the island prior to rescue two weeks later. A run-up of {{cvt|6.28|m}} on the island was determined, the highest recorded in Ishikawa Prefecture. In Kurikawashiri, Noto, inundation was observed {{cvt|700|m}} inland.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|title=Ritō de 2-shūkan koritsu no 3-nin o Jieitai heri ga kyūjo, denki suidō denwa tsukaezu 'yatto heri ga kitekureta'|trans-title=A Self-Defense Force helicopter rescues three people stranded on a remote island for two weeks without electricity, water, or telephone service. 'The helicopter finally came.'|script-title=ja:離島で２週間孤立の３人を自衛隊ヘリが救助、電気・水道・電話使えず「やっとヘリが来てくれた」|url=https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20240114-OYT1T50172/|access-date=16 January 2024|work=Yomiuri Shimbun|date=15 January 2024|language=ja}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|title=Shima no hanbun no taka-sa made oshiyoseru… Notohantō jishin no tsunami Wajima-shi Hegurajima de 'saidai 6 m chō' to hanmei ken'nai de mottomo takaku|trans-title=The tsunami from the Noto Peninsula earthquake surges to half the height of the island. The tsunami was found to be over 6 meters high on Hegura Island, Wajima City, making it the highest in the prefecture.|script-title=ja:島の半分の高さまで押し寄せる…能登半島地震の津波 輪島市舳倉島で「最大6m超」と判明 県内で最も高く|url=https://www.ishikawa-tv.com/news/itc/00002090/|publisher=Ishikawa TV|access-date=14 May 2024|date=14 May 2024|language=ja|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240514160705/https://www.ishikawa-tv.com/news/itc/00002090/|archive-date=14 May 2024|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Misaki Town, in Suzu City, had the highest recorded run up on the Noto Peninsula. Located on the tip of the peninsula, close to the rupture, waves up to {{cvt|5.64|m}} washed away several waterfront homes.

references.text: <ref name="nototsunamifieldsvy"/> Despite severe coastal damage and high run ups, no injuries or fatalities from the tsunami were recorded in Misaki. Extensive evacuation drills that had taken place multiple times a year in Misaki since the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami, saved lives when the Noto tsunami hit.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=ja: 石川・珠洲のある集落、津波の死者はゼロ　住民の命救った合言葉|trans-title= Zero deaths from tsunami in Suzu, Ishikawa Prefecture: A password that saved residents' lives|url=https://mainichi.jp/articles/20240211/k00/00m/040/065000c| website=mainichi.jp|date=February 11, 2024|access-date = January 11, 2025}}</ref>

sentences.text: In Jōetsu, Niigata, the locally-high run-up exceeding {{cvt|7|m}} flooded 15 homes along the Seki River bank. Beach houses and other buildings were also swept away. Ten fishing vessels capsized in the Ōgata, Niigata|Ogata Fishing Port area. Containers were also washed away and warehouses storing machinery were flooded. The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (MLIT) assessed that the tsunami inundated up to {{cvt|190|ha}} of land in Suzu, Noto and Shika, and damaged breakwaters in at least seven beaches. At least 120 maritime vessels were reported to have been sunk or capsized from the tsunami, while at least 70 percent of ports in Ishikawa Prefecture sustained damage. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Japan)|Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries said that 60 out of 69 fishing ports in Ishikawa Prefecture were affected by the tsunami, 18 of which were completely unusable and nine others partially functional.

content.title: Elsewhere along the Sea of Japan

sentences.text: The Korea Meteorological Administration warned that the coastlines of Gangwon Province, South Korea|Gangwon Province and Pohang in South Korea could experience a rise in sea levels. A {{cvt|0.45|m|adj=on}} tsunami was later reported to have occurred in Gangwon. Tsunamis with heights of {{cvt|0.66|m}} were recorded in Uljin County|Uljin; {{cvt|0.45|m}} in Sokcho and {{cvt|0.39|m}} in Gangneung. It is thought to be the first tsunami of over {{cvt|0.5|m}} observed in the country since 1993 Okushiri earthquake|1993. According to Yonhap News Agency, citing Korean Central Broadcasting Station|North Korean state radio, a tsunami warning was issued with waves of {{cvt|2.08|m}} potentially hitting the country's east coast.

sentences.text: Warnings were also issued in Russia for tsunami waves estimated to reach {{cvt|1|m|ft|0}}, particularly along the west coast of Sakhalin Island, where evacuations were said to be conducted, although Russia later said that no evacuations were taking place there. Tsunami warnings were also declared in parts of Primorsky Krai, Khabarovsk Krai, Vladivostok and Nakhodka. The Ministry of Emergency Situations (Russia)|Emergencies Ministry of Russia said "response teams are ready to deal with the possible consequences of a tsunami." Officials in Vladivostok later said "no tsunami was observed" while in Nakhodka, "the tsunami passed almost unnoticed." A {{cvt|0.63|m|adj=on}} wave was observed at Lazovsky District|Preobrazhenie in Primorsky Krai; at Kholmsk, it measured {{cvt|0.18|m}}.

The earthquake killed 572 people, including 344 people who died in the aftermath. A majority of direct deaths were due to collapsed homes. At least 562 deaths were confirmed in Ishikawa Prefecture; 204 in Wajima, 165 in Suzu, 60 in Noto, 50 in Nanao, 47 in Anamizu, 20 in Shika, 6 in Uchinada, Ishikawa|Uchinada, 5 in Hakui, Ishikawa|Hakui, 2 in Nakanoto, Ishikawa|Nakanoto, and 1 each in Kanazawa, Hakusan, Ishikawa|Hakusan and Komatsu, Ishikawa|Komatsu. with four more dying in Toyama Prefecture; two in Takaoka, Toyama|Takaoka and one each in Toyama City and Himi, Toyama|Himi. and two more were killed by the tsunami,<ref name="TSUNAMIDEATH"/> although the total number of tsunami deaths may be 26.<ref name="ts26"/>

sentences.text: By June 2024, there were 233 applications to local cities and towns to review deaths and register them as disaster-related. Three meetings have been held {{as of|2024|06|lc=y|post=;}} the first meeting in May resulted in 30 new cases being registered as related deaths. On 18 June, city officials were recommended to certify 22 new deaths. On 25 June, a joint panel discussion by the Ishikawa prefectural government and town officials recommended that 18 additional deaths be registered as disaster-related. If these additional cases are certified, it would bring the projected total death toll to 299. Five more applications read on the same day were subjected to further review.{{update inline|date=September 2024}}

sentences.text: In an assessment of 115 indirect deaths released in December 2024, "distress after the earthquake and fear of aftershocks" was cited as the cause in 89 fatalities, followed by "severed lifelines such as electricity and water" at 53 cases, and "life in evacuation centers" at 37 cases; 200 additional cases were still subject to review.

sentences.text: The Japanese government estimated the total cost of damage in Ishikawa, Toyama and Niigata to be ¥1.1-2.6 trillion (US$7.4-17.6 billion). Most of the cost was attributed to damaged homes, roads, ports and other infrastructure. Ishikawa Prefecture alone accounted for between ¥0.9–1.3 trillion (US$5.7–8.3 billion). At least 780 people across 30 districts in remote villages were isolated due to damaged roads and landslides and required helicopters to be reached. Many of the collapsed houses in Wajima were traditional wooden structures that were built prior to current building regulations that were imposed in 1981, Information from 2018 also revealed that more than half of buildings in Wajima did not follow these regulations. Around 66 percent of residences in Suzu were wooden homes that were built before 1980,

sentences.text: At least 152,967 structures, including 115,786 houses, 443 public buildings and 36,738 of unspecified use, were damaged across Ishikawa, including 24,694 which were partially or completely destroyed. A fire occurred in the city at around 17:00. Due to damaged roads, firefighters were unable to extinguish the flames. The fire consumed an estimated 200 buildings, including many homes, and the Asaichi morning market, a 1,000-year-old shopping district and tourist attraction that hosted about 200 stalls. An area of up to {{cvt|48,000|m2}} was affected by the fire, which experts said was exacerbated by the loss of water supply and the tsunami warning, which prevented firefighters from responding immediately to the blaze. The Fire and Disaster Management Agency later said that the fire may have been caused by electrical wiring that had been damaged by the earthquake. At least 516 people were injured in the city. In the city, 3,848 homes were severely damaged or destroyed and 1,754 were partially damaged. Damage and casualties in the city were exacerbated by Noto earthquake swarm|previous earthquakes, most notably a 2023 Noto earthquake|M<sub>JMA</sub>6.5 event in May 2023 which damaged or destroyed a quarter of Suzu's houses. Many people were still residing in these damaged houses at the time of the earthquake. The mayor of Suzu said about 4,000 to 5,000 households of the city's 6,000 were no longer habitable, adding that damage was "catastrophic".

sentences.text: The Ishikawa Nanao Police Station said collapsed homes trapped people before they were rescued. A spokesperson at Wajima Municipal Hospital said people had broken bones or were injured by falling objects. At least 116 people were injured and 7,462 houses in Shika were damaged, including 3,032 which collapsed or sustained severe damage. In Anamizu, 258 people were injured, 387 houses collapsed, 1,289 were partially destroyed and 1,647 were damaged;

sentences.text: In Noto, 54 people were injured, 1,261 homes were completely or partially destroyed and 4,511 others were damaged, along with 3,945 buildings. Five of the affected houses were destroyed by fires. Operations of the Noto Airport were suspended after five cracks as long as {{cvt|10|m}} appeared on the runway; the terminal of the airport also sustained damage. Access roads leading to the airport were blocked, while about 500 passengers were left stranded inside the facility, In Nanao, Ishikawa|Nanao, 37 people were injured, 5,527 houses fully or partially collapsed and 11,287 others were damaged. In Kanazawa, nine people were injured and 20,656 buildings were damaged, including 284 which collapsed or sustained severe damage.

On Sado Island, four buildings were razed, 31 were partially destroyed and 438 were damaged. Two residents of the prefecture were also killed in Ishikawa. At least 1,066 houses collapsed or were severely damaged and 21,627 others were partially damaged, mostly in the cities of Himi, Toyama|Himi, Takaoka, Toyama|Takaoka and Imizu. 12 houses partially collapsed and 820 others were damaged, including 45 in Awara, Fukui|Awara. Five injuries were also reported in Osaka Prefecture|Osaka, and one each in Gifu Prefecture|Gifu and Aichi Prefecture|Aichi.<ref name="78Dead1"/> In Nagano Prefecture, 21 houses were damaged.<ref name="FDMA"/>

sentences.text: Cracked roads and broken water mains were reported in the cities of Himi, Toyama|Himi and Oyabe, Toyama|Oyabe, Toyama Prefecture. Residents of Himi experienced water outages lasting nearly two weeks, with orders to conserve water lasting until February. In Toyama prefecture, underground snow-removal equipment for city roads was damaged in multiple areas, resulting in the deployment of snowplows and other equipment following heavy snowfall on 23 January. Soil liquefaction|Liquefaction occurred in Uozu and in Niigata (city)|Niigata city; sewer pipes also ruptured and many homes were left without water. Thirty homes in Nishi-ku, Niigata|Nishi-ku were damaged. The Onohiyoshi Shrine in Kanazawa also sustained damage. A landslide struck the main expressway between Toyama and Kanazawa, ripping apart several hundred meters of roadway. Sections of Japan National Route 8 was buried by landslides in Jōetsu, while track foundations caved in at the JR Echigo Line. A bridge along the Kurobe Gorge Railway, a popular tourist line, was damaged due to falling rocks. Cracks also appeared at the Nōetsu Expressway.<ref name="25jan"/>

sentences.text: Around 260 convenience stores in the affected areas belonging to 7-11 and Family Mart were closed, while deliveries were delayed due to road closures. NTT Docomo, Rakuten Mobile, The site's {{cvt|4|m}} high seawall was found to have tilted by around several centimeters following the earthquake. At the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant in Niigata prefecture, water spilled from the fuel pools of two reactors due to the force of the earthquake. with five of them suffering complete destruction of their facilities.

references.text: <ref name="jt2"/> Japan Post also suspended services to the Noto Peninsula until 12 January due to road closures.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan Post resumes parcel services in 3 areas in Ishikawa|url=https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240112_14/|access-date=12 January 2024|publisher=NHK World-Japan|date=12 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240112141839/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240112_14/|archive-date=12 January 2024|url-status=dead}}</ref>

At Shika Nuclear Power Plant, an explosion occurred near the power transformer of the No. 2 reactor, while the transformer at the No. 1 reactor was rendered inoperable due to an oil spill.<ref name="nhktsunami2"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Systems to supply power to nuclear plant in Ishikawa partially unusable|url=https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240102_33/|access-date=2 January 2024|publisher=NHK World-Japan|date=2 January 2024|archive-date=3 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240103203417/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240102_33/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

In Shika, water was being rationed daily at six litres per person following the earthquake.

sentences.text: The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology reported that 276 educational facilities had been damaged by the earthquake, particularly in Niigata, Ishikawa, Toyama, Fukui and Shiga prefectures. It also said 39 schools in four prefectures had been converted to evacuation shelters. The ministry also reported damage to 20 cultural sites in Toyama and Niigata prefectures. Several stone lanterns collapsed at the Zuiryū-ji (Toyama)|Zuiryū-ji temple in Takaoka, Toyama|Takaoka, which is a designated National Treasure (Japan)|National Treasure, while a slope collapsed at the Sado mine. About 350 people across evacuation centers were infected by COVID-19 or the common flu, while at least 40 cases of gastrointestinal illnesses such as norovirus were detected. In Suzu, a 90-year-old woman was rescued from a collapsed house after 124 hours.

sentences.text: A review conducted after the earthquake found that Ishikawa Prefecture's disaster preparedness plan had been insufficient to handle the event. It found that the plan had not been significantly updated since 1997 and made only provisions for a magnitude 7.0 earthquake that would be localized in scope and classified as a low-level disaster with only three deaths, 120 destroyed buildings and 2,781 evacuees. Exactly one year after the earthquake, it was revealed the Japanese government estimated only 40 direct deaths from the earthquake.

sentences.text: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced the establishment of a special emergency center to gather and disseminate information on the earthquake and tsunami. He later announced the deployment of 2,000 {{abbr|JSDF|Japan Self-Defense Forces}} personnel to the affected region, with 8,500 others on standby. About 20 {{abbr|JSDF|Japan Self-Defense Forces}} aircraft were also dispatched to survey the damage. An additional 2,000 firefighters and 1,000 police officers were also deployed to assist in rescue operations. About 3,000 rescuers were sent to the Noto Peninsula alone. By 4 January, at least 150 people had been rescued, while at least 2,000 of the 10,000 evacuees from Wajima had received humanitarian aid.

sentences.text: The Japanese government announced that it would allocate 4 billion yen ($28 million) from reserve funds to use in disaster relief efforts and increased the number of {{abbr|JSDF|Japan Self-Defense Forces}} personnel involved in the response to 6,300. Defence Minister Kihara added that Mitsubishi H-60|UH60JA helicopters were to be used in relief efforts, in their first major deployment since the 2023 Miyakojima helicopter crash in April. The Japanese government also announced that families whose houses were completely destroyed or severely damaged would receive aid amounting to 3 million yen ($20,000). Kishida later said that the government would allocate a total of 100 billion yen ($690 million) in reconstruction efforts and increase its reserve funds to $6.9 billion in the upcoming annual budget to ensure support for recovery efforts.

sentences.text: Ishikawa, Niigata, Toyama and Fukui prefectures requested financial support for 47 municipalities under the Disaster Relief Act, under which the national government is expected to cover 50 to 90 percent of expenses for disaster response and rehabilitation. The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare|Japanese health ministry also instructed hospitals to offer health insurance coverage to patients affected by the quake, including those without insurance certificates and opened a telephone interpreting service in 23 languages to help medical workers handle foreign patients in the affected areas. Authorities in Ishikawa prefecture also opened an email help line to assist affected residents and tourists. By May, the number of displaced had fallen to 4,606, while about 3,780 households remained without water. As of December 2024, more than 200 people remained in shared emergency shelters.

sentences.text: On 4 January, the Japan Coast Guard began searching its coast with an aircraft and patrol boat for people missing; presumably swept away by the tsunami. At least one person was declared missing from the tsunami. At least two people were rescued after the expiration of the 72-hour survival window in Wajima on 4 January. Large holes in roads and landslides made rescue efforts challenging four days after the earthquake. Snowy weather conditions also affected rescue efforts, with snowfall reaching {{cvt|10|cm}} in several areas and raising concerns of additional building collapses. Snowfall significantly affected rescuers' ability to deliver supplies to isolated villages and recover survivors. Power was also cut due to snow, disabling cell phones.

sentences.text: By 3 January, about 31,800 people were living in shelters following the earthquake, with about 27,700 sheltering in 336 evacuation centers in Ishikawa prefecture alone. The government said it had secured about 6,500 public housing units for evacuees to resettle across the country. A month after the earthquake, around 14,000 people remained displaced due to the disaster and about 2,867 people continued to live in damaged homes.

sentences.text: Local authorities announced plans to transfer students from schools in Wajima that had been converted to evacuation centers to schools in Hakusan, Ishikawa|Hakusan and Kanazawa, followed by around 140 junior high school students from Suzu and Noto. Fifty students from a high school in Wajima were transferred to Kai, Yamanashi prefecture, with 600 others expected to arrive in April. Schools in some of the affected areas resumed on 15 January, along with garbage-collection services in Wajima. At least 44 schools in the affected areas remain closed {{as of|2024|01|22|alt=as of 22 January}} but gradually reopened, with the remaining seven schools reopening in Wajima on 6 February. Applicants from Ishikawa Prefecture who were unable to take the Common Test for University Admissions held on 13–14 January due to the earthquake were allowed to undertake makeup examinations scheduled later in the month.

sentences.text: On 14 January, Kishida made his first visit to the disaster zone, where he held an aerial inspection over Ishikawa Prefecture and visited evacuation centers in Wajima and Suzu. On 25 January, the Japanese government unveiled a disaster recovery package in which residents were exempted from the cost of demolishing their homes and would receive around $20,000 to rebuild destroyed or severely damaged houses. It also called for the construction of wooden and conventional makeshift prefabricated dwellings. The government also pledged to shoulder up to 75 percent of costs in resuming operations at small and midsized businesses, with a limit of $10 million. It also pledged to support the replacement of affected agricultural machinery and fishing boats, as well as the recovery of traditional industries in the area such as Wajima-nuri lacquerware. The government also said it was planning to shoulder half the hotel fees for tourists in the Hokuriku Region with a limit of $135 per stay to promote tourism. The government said the package would be funded by the national budget's reserve funds in the 2023 and 2024 fiscal years.

sentences.text: Kansai Electric Power Company, Tokyo Electric Power Company and Hokuriku Electric Power Company said they were inspecting their nuclear power plants for abnormalities. Both the Kansai with the reactors at the latter's Shika Nuclear Power Plant in Ishikawa Prefecture having been closed for inspections at the time of the earthquake. However, a cumulative oil spillage of 19,800 liters at two of the reactors was later revealed, partially impacting the plant's ability to receive power from external sources. Hokuriku Electric Power Company subsequently said that repairs at the facility would take more than six months. Eighteen of the Shika nuclear plant's 116 radiation monitoring posts were also rendered offline by the earthquake. Ground deformation, including subsidence, was also recorded in 80 locations inside the plant compound.<ref name="shika4"/>

sentences.text: By 29 January, electricity had been restored to 80 percent of households in Wajima and Suzu, and 99 percent in Nanao, Noto, Anamizu and Shika. Ishikawa's governor Hiroshi Hase said power was expected to be fully restored in the prefecture by 31 January.

sentences.text: Shinkansen services were suspended in central and eastern parts of Japan following the earthquake, stranding at least 1,400 passengers aboard four stalled trains between Toyama Station|Toyama and Kanazawa Station|Kanazawa for about 11 hours. Local train services were also halted for up to 24 hours following the earthquake, stranding about 1,000 passengers aboard express trains. Several major highways in the affected areas were also closed. All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines cancelled flights to Toyama, Ishikawa, and Niigata prefectures for the rest of 1 January.

sentences.text: By the morning of 3 January, Japan Railways partially resumed services, The {{abbr|MLIT|Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism}} confirmed that Noto Airport would remain closed until 4 January. Following repairs, the airport reopened to {{abbr|JSDF|Japan Self-Defense Forces}} aircraft on 11 January, while All Nippon Airways resumed commercial services to and from the airport on 27 January, albeit in a limited capacity until the end of February. The Noto Railway resumed full operations on 6 April.

sentences.text: Due to blocked roads, humanitarian aid was sent to the peninsula using ships, while other isolated areas were accessed through helicopters. In light of the difficulties in providing aid, Ishikawa Prefecture asked individuals to refrain from sending aid, instead limiting the call to corporations only. By 4 January, authorities had delivered about 240,000 meals, 500 packages of powdered milk, and 190,000 bottles of drinking water to the affected areas.

sentences.text: On the evening of 2 January, a 2024 Haneda Airport runway collision|runway collision occurred at Haneda Airport in Tokyo between a Japan Coast Guard De Havilland Canada Dash 8|DHC-8 aircraft carrying humanitarian aid to earthquake victims in Niigata and Japan Airlines Flight 516, an Airbus A350|A350-900 from New Chitose Airport landing at Haneda, destroying both aircraft. All 379 people aboard the JAL plane were evacuated; however, 15 sustained injuries. The captain of the Coast Guard plane escaped with critical injuries, while the remaining five crew members were killed.

sentences.text: Fundraising campaigns across the country collected a total amount of ¥10 billion ($67 million) for relief aid. Private organizations raised at least $8 million in crowdfunding drives for relief aid, while the Ishikawa prefectural government began accepting cash donations at its offices, including those in Tokyo and Osaka, while announcing plans to open a bank account for further donations. By 24 January, the prefectural government said that it had received a total of at least ¥11 billion ($74.4 million) in donations, which was augmented by donations amounting to $8.1 million for the local Japanese Red Cross Society (JRCS) and $2.4 million to the local Central Community Chest of Japan (CCCJ) branch. The {{abbr|CCCJ|Central Community Chest of Japan}} also established the Disaster Relief Volunteer & NPO Support Fund (VolSup) to support {{abbr|NPOs|Non-Profit Organizations}} and their activities in providing help to victims.

sentences.text: Apparel companies, including Gunze, Fast Retailing and Onward Holdings, donated at least 170,000 items for victims of the earthquake. About 110 hotels and inns volunteered to take in 3,000 people displaced by the earthquake. JR Freight announced that it would carry humanitarian aid to the affected areas for free. Nintendo announced that it will donate ¥50 million via the {{abbr|JRCS|Japanese Red Cross Society}} for disaster relief, with The Pokémon Company also having donated the same amount earlier in the month. KDDI offered 550 Starlink routers to shelters, government offices and medical teams operating in areas affected by the earthquake. In February 2024, the Japan Sumo Association donated ¥10 million to Ishikawa Prefecture, plus ¥5 million collected from spectators at the 2024 in sumo#January|January tournament in Tokyo. Two months later, in April 2024, the association also organized its first {{Nihongo3|charity sumo|勧進相撲|kanjin-sumō}} tournament in 62 years with an additional ¥27 million raised during the event.

sentences.text: The {{abbr|JRCS|Japanese Red Cross Society}} dispatched staff members and Emergency Medical Relief Teams to Ishikawa prefecture, focusing on hospitals, social welfare facilities, and evacuation centers. It also deployed Disaster Medical Coordination teams, nurses, and provided psychosocial support to affected people. The {{abbr|JRCS|Japanese Red Cross Society}} also installed a temporary water distribution system at evacuation centers in Nanao, which began supplying water on 22 January by purifying water from a swimming pool.

references.text: <ref>{{cite press release|title=Operation Update No.30 : 2024 Noto Peninsula Earthquake: The Japanese Red Cross Society's Response|date=20 February 2024|publisher=Japanese Red Cross Society|url=https://www.jrc.or.jp/english/relief/2024NotoPeninsulaEarthquake.html|access-date=28 February 2024|lang=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Taiwanese government announced ¥60 million in aid to support rescue operations and relief. A donation account was also created, while a fundraising campaign collected over NT$540 million ($17.2 million) from the private sector. United States Ambassador Rahm Emmanuel pledged an initial $100,000 in humanitarian aid to Japan and logistical support from the United States military. Japan said it only had plans to accept aid from the United States despite offers from other countries including Taiwan and China. In a statement from Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshimasa Hayashi, the country was "not accepting any personnel or material aid at the moment given the situation on the ground and the efforts that would be required to receive them." South Korea also said that it would provide $3 million in humanitarian aid. The Thai embassy in Tokyo sent 2,500 kilograms of food and other relief items to Ishikawa Prefecture.

sentences.text: From 3 May to 2 June 2024, a special event was held in Nanao, Ishikawa|Nanao by manga author Makoto Ojiro, aiming to support the city. With the help of the manga publisher Shogakukan, the proceeds from the sales of her manga, ''Insomniacs After School''—which is set in Nanao—will be donated to the city's relief fund for one year, from 16 April 2024 to 15 April 2025.

sentences.text: The aftermath of the earthquake included a major humanitarian impact in the worst affected regions, as well as a national economic impact. Preliminary findings by Japanese financial services company Nomura Securities suggested the temporary stagnation of economic activity would push down Gross domestic product|nominal GDP by 23 to 50 billion yen. Nomura estimated that the most affected cities, such as Suzu, Ishikawa|Suzu, Wajima, Ishikawa|Wajima and Nanao, Ishikawa|Nanao, will experience a temporary pause in economic activity. NHK added that losses are likely to increase, as the damage to roads, housing and factories has not been considered in the research. However, it is estimated that the wider impact on supply chains may be less than those compared to the 2016 Kumamoto earthquakes. Tourism in the affected areas suffered negatively, with 10,000 people cancelling their bookings in Toyama Prefecture alone, leading to losses of about 140 million yen ($970,000).<ref name="Kurobe"/>

In total, around 5,000 creatures died in the aquarium following damage from the earthquake to its water circulation equipment and pipes.

sentences.text: The perceived slow response drew widespread criticism from the public. Anger was directed at Kishida for his delayed deployment of the {{abbr|JSDF|Japan Self-Defense Forces}}. He was also criticized for only visiting an evacuation center briefly two weeks after the earthquake. In Wajima, there were over 4,000 registrations for temporary housing units with baths and water heating, of which, only 550 were constructed by mid-February. Only 40 of the 456 temporary housing units in Suzu were completed. Local officials said about 14,000 temporary housing units would be ready by the end of March. Despite reassurance by the government, local residents' confidence remains low due to living conditions in evacuation centers and the delayed response. By the end of February, more than 11,000 people remained in temporary shelters.

sentences.text: Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako's annual Japanese New Year|New Year appearance and greetings to the public on 2 January was cancelled due to the earthquake. At a function in Tokyo marking his first public appearance for the year on 15 January, the emperor offered his first public condolences for those affected and praised relief workers for their efforts. He also sent a message of sympathy to Ishikawa governor Hiroshi Hase. The Imperial couple finally visited the area on 22 March and on 12 April. Prime Minister Kishida also postponed a ceremonial New Year visit to the Ise Shrine due to the earthquake.

references.text: <ref name="f24-2"/> The Imperial Household Agency said it was the first time that the event was cancelled due to a natural disaster. It also reported that the Imperial couple "wish that rescue operations and fire-fighting efforts in affected areas will progress as quickly as possible amid the severe cold weather."<ref>{{cite news|title=Imperial family's New Year Greeting to general public canceled|url=https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240102_13/|access-date=2 January 2024|publisher=NHK World-Japan|date=2 January 2024|archive-date=2 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240102204234/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240102_13/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

sentences.text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un sent a Telegraphy|telegram to Japanese Prime Minister of Japan|Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, his condolences and wished the Japanese people a fast recovery. It marked the first time Kim has sent his condolences after a natural disaster, and the first time he has sent a telegram to Kishida. It was also the first time that North Korea had sent official condolences to Japan since 1995. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese sent condolences and said Australia was ready to send any assistance to Japan. Philippine president Bongbong Marcos offered to send assistance to Japan, International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva and Pope Francis also expressed their prayers to the victims of the earthquake. The United States announced preparations for military logistics, food and aid. United States Forces Japan remained "ready to support our Japanese Allies during this difficult time."

sentences.text: Misinformation about the earthquake spread on social media platforms such as Twitter. Users falsely linked a November 2023 video of an Submarine earthquake|underwater earthquake in Indonesia, photos of the 2011 Tōhoku and 2016 Kumamoto earthquakes|2016 Kumamoto earthquakes and a 2021 Atami landslide|2021 landslide following the earthquake. False claims were also made of the earthquake being Induced seismicity|man-made, with a video citing a previous List of nuclear weapons tests of North Korea|nuclear weapons test by North Korea. Such accounts have been popularly dubbed {{nihongo|"impression zombies"|:ja:インプレゾンビ|インプレゾンビ|imprezombi}} and are a growing phenomenon on the social media platform following Elon Musk's acquisition and alteration to monetization policies for its "premium" users.<ref name="IZ"/>

sentences.text: Former Japanese Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama incorrectly claimed the earthquake caused a fire at the Shika Nuclear Power Plant and suggested that impacts of the earthquake had been deliberately downplayed to restart the plant. While there had been a minimal oil spill at two of the reactors, there was no impact on the plant.
